questions.question: A patient exposed to radiation presents with severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea within a few days. Based on these symptoms, what is the expected radiation dose that has likely caused this Gastrointestinal Syndrome?
questions.explanation: emerging primarily in the 5-20 Gy range. It is characterised by severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, indicating serious gastrointestinal distress from radiation exposure. Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS): It refers to symptoms following whole-body or significant partial-body exposure to high doses of radiation (>1 Gy). LD50/60, or Lethal Dose 50/60 , is the radiation dose expected to cause death in 50% of the exposed population within 60 days. An LD50/60 of approximately 4.5 Gy indicates that this level of whole-body radiation can lead to 50% mortality without medical intervention. Clinical Phases of ARS: Phase Time Post-Exposure Symptoms/Outcomes Prodromal Phase 0–2 days Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, fever, headache, early skin erythema (suggesting significant exposure >2 Gy ) Latent Phase 2–20 days Temporary symptom improvement; abnormal lab results (lymphopenia, granulocytopenia) despite feeling well Manifest Illness Phase 21–60 days Symptoms vary by syndrome: Hematopoietic syndrome ( 1-8 Gy , death in months): Gastrointestinal syndrome ( >5 Gy , death in 2 weeks) Neurovascular syndrome ( >20 Gy , death within 48 hours) Final Phase Recovery or Death The outcome depends on the absorbed dose, dose rate, and exposure heterogeneity. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3863169/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3863296/

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute abdominal pain and altered bowel habits. The physician suspects abdominal pathology and considers various imaging studies, weighing concerns about radiation exposure. Which imaging modality would expose the patient to the highest level of radiation?
questions.explanation: diagnostic modalities like CT/radionuclide studies have high radiation exposures. Radiation Level associated with various imaging modalities & Level of Hazards: Hazard Level Modality Investigation Effective Dose (mSv) DANGER PET/CT/Radionuclide Studies CT Abdomen 10 CT Thorax 8 PET 5 Bone Scan 4 CT Head 2 - 3.5 WARNING Diagnostic procedures– multiple views Barium Enema 7 Barium Meal follow-through 3 Barium Meal 2.6 Barium Swallow 1.5 Micturating Cystourethrogram (MCU) 1.2 SAFE Spot radiographs: Only 1 or 2 X-ray exposures to the patient X-ray Lumbar Spine 1 - 1.5 X-ray Abdomen 0.7 - 1.2 Hip Joint 0.4 Skull 0.06 CXR (PA View) 0.02 Limb & Joint (Except Hip) <0.01 Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2996147/

questions.question: A 20-year-old female has recently started working in the radiology department and is concerned about radiation exposure. She seeks advice from the occupational health department. According to AERB guidelines, what is the maximum dose limit for occupational workers exposed to whole-body radiation in a year?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) 30 mSv According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) guidelines, the maximum dose limit for occupational workers exposed to whole-body radiation in any given year is 30 mSv. However, the average annual dose limit over five years should not exceed 20 mSv per year. Dose limitations as per AERB (Atomic Energy Regulatory Board) guidelines are: Part of the body Occupational Exposure Public Exposure Whole body 20 mSv per year (averaged over 5 years) (Option B) 30 mSV in a year (maximum) (Option C) 1mSv per year Lens of the eyes 150 mSv per year 15 mSv per year (Option D) Skin and Extremities (hand and feet) 500 mSv in a year 50 mSv per year (Option A) Pregnant radiation workers (once pregnancy is declared) 1 mSv (for the embryo/fetus) 2 mSv (for the pregnant women) - As per NCRP (National Council on Radiation Protection and Management) guidelines, the recommended exposure dose limit for pregnant ladies is: < 5mSv during the entire pregnancy, or < 0.5mSv per month Reference: David Sutton’s Textbook of Radiology and Imaging, Volume I, 7th Edition, Page 459, 460.

questions.question: A 25-year-old male who recently joined the radiology department was instructed to wear the device shown in the image. Which of the following statements about this device is incorrect?

options.A: Assess the amount of radiation exposure
options.C: Should be sent for dose monitoring every 3 months
options.D: It is worn over the lead apron

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) It is worn over the lead apron The image depicts a TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge which is worn beneath the lead apron to accurately measure the radiation dose (Option A) that penetrates the body. TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge Purpose It is worn by individuals in radiation-exposed environments, such as medical imaging or nuclear facilities, to track their radiation dose and ensure it stays within safe limits. Location Worn beneath the lead apron (as lead apron cuts off some radiation) Duration According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) of India, TLD badges are generally replaced and analyzed every 3 months to assess cumulative radiation exposure. (Option C) Composition Thermoluminescent phosphor crystals : (Option B) Calcium sulfate dysprosium Lithium fluoride Lithium borate Berrylium oxide Principle

questions.question: A 50-year-old female patient with a history of breast cancer is scheduled for a follow-up PET scan. During the consultation, she expresses concern about the long-term effects of radiation exposure. Which of the following statements regarding the stochastic effects of radiation exposure is correct?

options.A: The severity of the effects is dose-dependent
options.B: It can also result in radiation-induced cataracts
options.C: No threshold dose is required for the occurrence

questions.explanation: of radiation effect that does not require a threshold dose for occurrence. Types of Radiation Effects: Deterministic Effects Stochastic Effects Threshold dose Required Not required (occur by chance, at any dose) (Option C) Severity Dose-dependent (Option A) Dose-independent Dose increased Severity increases The probability of occurrence increases Examples Radiation-induced cataract (Option B) Skin erythema (most common side effect) Radiation-induced cancer (most common is Leukemia) Congenital malformations Mutations

questions.question: In the context of the ALARA (As Low As Reasonably Achievable) principle, which of the following strategies is not aligned with minimising radiation exposure for healthcare workers during interventional procedures?

options.A: Increasing the distance between the operator and the radiation source.
options.B: Continuous fluoroscopy instead of Pulsed fluoroscopy
options.C: Implementing lead shielding and personal protective equipment (PPE).
options.D: Reducing the duration of time the patient is exposed to radiation.

questions.explanation: does not align with the ALARA Principle. ALARA (As Low As Reasonably Achievable) Principle: It serves as a guiding framework for minimising radiation exposure during diagnostic and interventional procedures. Its core application is to reduce radiation exposure while maintaining the quality of medical procedures. Strategies for reducing radiation exposure: Increase distance (Option A ruled out) : According to the inverse square law, radiation exposure decreases significantly with increased distance from the source. Use shielding (Option C ruled out) : Employ physical barriers to block radiation, such as personal protective equipment (PPE) like lead aprons and thyroid collars, along with architectural shielding in facilities (e.g., concrete walls in X-ray rooms). Reduce time (Option D) : Minimizing the duration of exposure during procedures is crucial, as shorter exposure times directly reduce the risk for both patients and healthcare workers. Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK565909/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557499/#:~:t ext=The%20As%20Low%20as%20Reasonably,of%20diagnosing%20and%20treating%20patients.

questions.question: A 28-year-old woman arrives at the emergency department with acute abdominal pain. The attending physician is considering an abdominal X-ray. What does the "10-day rule" advise regarding X-ray exposure for women of childbearing age?

options.A: A gap of at least 10 days between two successive X-rays.
options.B: Avoid non-urgent X-rays within 10 days post-menstruation
options.C: Perform X-rays during the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle.
options.D: X-rays should be avoided 10 days before menstruation.

questions.explanation: guideline used to minimize the risk of radiation exposure to a potentially pregnant woman. Proposed by the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP). It states that radiological examinations of the lower abdomen and pelvis should be conducted, whenever possible, within the first 10 days following the onset of menstruation unless pregnancy is excluded. In early pregnancy, radiation exposure, especially during organogenesis (weeks 3-8 post-conception), can lead to teratogenic effects (e.g., congenital anomalies), increased risk of miscarriage, or even fetal growth restriction. This rule helps to prevent radiation exposure during early pregnancy that can potentially harm the developing embryo. Reference: DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th Edition, Page 606

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for a CT scan to evaluate abdominal pain. The radiologist aims to ensure adequate visualization of the bowel without creating significant contrast between the bowel contents and surrounding tissues. Which of the following is a neutral contrast agent appropriate for this procedure?
questions.explanation: ensuring adequate visualization of the bowel. Contrast media are substances used in medical imaging to enhance the visibility of structures within the body. Type of Contrast Media Description Examples Positive contrast media Appear white on X-ray images due to greater attenuation of X-rays than surrounding tissues. Barium (Option A), Iodinated solutions (Option B) Negative contrast media Appear black due to less attenuation of X-rays than surrounding tissues. Air (Option C) Carbon dioxide Neutral contrast media Do not significantly alter X-ray attenuation, providing balanced contrast without adding brightness or darkness to the images. Water Mannitol (draws water into bowel loop) Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, 7th Edition, Page 501, 532

questions.question: A 35-year-old female is scheduled for an ERCP using the contrast mentioned below. Which type of contrast agent is it?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Non-ionic Monomer Iohexol is an iodine contrast agent that is classified as a Non-ionic monomer . The commonly used iodine contrast agents are water soluble and are classified into ionic and non-ionic groups based on their osmolality and chemical structure. The iodine particle ratio helps decide the osmolality of the drug, where high osmolar drugs pose a higher risk for kidney damage. Iodine Particle Ratio Ionic = 2 particles Non-ionic = 1 particle Monomer = 3 iodine Dimer = 6 iodine Ionic Monomer Ionic Dimer Non-ionic Monomer Non-ionic Dimer 3:2 (High osmolality) 3:1 (Low osmolality) 3:1 6:1 Iodine Contrast Routes of administration Intravenous and Intra-arterial Indications Commonly used for contrast in CECT (3D X-ray), Interventional Radiology, and X-rays like as in Intravenous pyelogram Micturating cystourethrogram Hysterosalpingography Retrograde pyelography ERCP- Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography

questions.question: A 42-year-old female with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with severe abdominal pain and diarrhoea. The gastroenterologist is considering performing a barium study to assess her condition. Which of the following conditions would contraindicate using a barium study in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) exacerbation Barium contrast study is contraindicated in Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) exacerbation ( acute inflammation) as it poses a risk of perforation, where barium can leak into the abdominal cavity, leading to peritonitis and severe complications. Barium contrast is a water-insoluble substance used in imaging studies to enhance the visualization of the GI tract, aiding in the assessment of conditions like gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), esophageal strictures, tumors, diverticulosis, ulcers and motility disorders. Contraindications of Barium Study: GI Perforation : Can lead to peritonitis or mediastinitis. Bowel Obstruction : May exacerbate the obstruction and increase the risk of perforation. Tracheoesophageal Fistula : Risk of aspiration leading to pneumonia; iso-osmolar or low-osmolar non-ionic contrast is preferred. Acute Abdominal Inflammation : Risk of perforation and severe complications. Types of Barium Studies Type Conditions Barium Swallow To evaluate normal swallowing function. Suspected oesophagal disorders (e.g., strictures, tumours) Achalasia cardia Zenkers diverticulum Hiatus hernia Barium Meal To evaluate normal gastric emptying Evaluation of gastric and duodenal conditions (e.g., ulcers, carcinoma, pyloric stenosis) Barium Meal Follow-Through Assessment of small bowel disorders Malabsorption syndrome (Option A) Ileocecal TB (Option C) Barium Enema Assessment of lower gastrointestinal tract (e.g. Colonic carcinoma) (Option B) Reference: David Sutton’s Textbook of Radiology and Imaging, Volume 1, 8th edition, page 2024, 2036, 2090, 2240, 1139

questions.question: A 35-year-old pregnant woman is being assessed for suspected appendicitis. An abdominal ultrasound shows inflammation but in limited detail. What is the best contrast agent to enhance USG?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Sulfur Hexafluoride microbubbles In contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS), microbubbles or microspheres , such as those found in Sonovist and Levovist , contain sulfur hexafluoride gas encapsulated in a phospholipid shell. These microbubbles improve the visualization of blood flow and enhance the imaging of vascular structures and lesions. Another type of microbubble in CEUS consists of octafluoropropane gas within a phospholipid shell. Contrast agents for USG Examples Sonovue (sulfur hexafluoride) Lumason (sulfur hexafluoride) Definity (perflutren) Sonozoid (perflubutane) Preferred route Intravenous Eliminated by Lungs (hence safe in Renal conditions) Indications Liver lesions Micturating cystosonography Renal lesions Obstruction in Crohn's disease Evaluation of Aortic aneurysm repair Adverse Effects It is the safest contrast media and rarely causes mild anaphylactoid reactions. Barium sulfate (Option A) is the most commonly used contrast agent for identifying gastrointestinal tract issues such as ulcers, tumours, strictures, or inflammation. It is not water-soluble and is given orally or rectally. Iodinated contrast agents (Option B) are water-soluble and are widely used for X-rays, CT scans, and interventional radiology. However, they are highly nephrotoxic and should be used with caution in patients with renal impairment only after evaluating renal function. Saline solution (Option C) enhances the visualisation of internal structures, such as in saline infusion sonohysterography and hysterosalpingo-contrast sonography, which is mixed with air to improve the visibility of fallopian tubes and identify peritoneal spills. Reference: David Sutton’s Textbook of Radiology and Imaging, Volume 1, 8th edition, Page 496, 497, 3545

questions.question: A 70-year-old patient with multiple comorbidities is being evaluated for contrast-enhanced imaging. The healthcare team is assessing risk factors for contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN). Which of the following is NOT considered a risk factor for CIN?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) History of asthma Previous history of asthma is not considered a risk factor for nephrotoxicity related to contrast media. Contrast-induced Nephropathy: ( Contrast-Induced Acute Kidney Injury (AKI) ) Defined as an increase in serum creatinine by > 0.5 mg/dL or a > 25% rise from the baseline within 3 days of contrast administration, without any other clear cause. Patients at higher risk for CIN typically include those with: A history of renal disease Diabetes (Option A ruled out) Use of metformin (Option B ruled out) Use of aminoglycosides Chronic use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (Option C ruled out) Prevention: Hydration with intravenous saline (0.9%) is recommended at a rate of 100 mL/h, starting 12 hours before the angiography and continuing for 12 hours after the procedure. Reference: Grainger and Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page 2068
